Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] Re: The "new media types are evil" meme
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=511039257; y=XWFsS3giGXRLJ5Q0cX9TWVOLrFzwz9rl0AKPW9rL41-egjdh0nbc3uo6dEgGFaDvc2lk_kVCtZcUFA8
X-Yahoo-Profile: mikekelly8762348

Hi Jan,

Comments inline:

On Tue, Jan 3, 2012 at 12:13 PM, Jan Algermissen=

<jan.algermissen@...> wrote:
>
> On Jan 3, 2012, at 10:54 AM, Mike =
Kelly wrote:
>
>> There's nothing inherently wrong about statements like "t=
he semantics
>> of POST requests vary for different resources".
>
> See, th=
is is where you get it wrong. The semantics of the request are always the s=
ame.

As I explained; the _network-visible semantics_ are always the same
f=
rom POST's definition in HTTP. HTTP will likely provide other types
of visi=
ble semantic such as conditionality, content-length, etc.

But - the intent=
/application semantics/whatever-word-you-want of POST
requests aren't the s=
ame between resources. For example; the meaning
of a POST to a resource tha=
t constructs hover-donkeys is not the same
as the meaning of a POST to a re=
source which submits condescending,
rhetoric-filled posts to a mailing list=
.

> The is no shared understanding that the server needs to know about.

O=
f course there is - a server has to establish a specific
understanding of a=
n incoming POST body to a resource in order to
process it in a specific way=
.

> The server only receives a 'process this' request and the target resou=
rce will process the request entity. The server does not need to care about=
 anything else.

What distinction are you drawing between the processing th=
e 'server'
does and the processing the 'resource' does, and why? I find you=
r
interpretation extremely confused, personally.

> The client develops an =
expectation (from previous hypermedia) about the effect of the POST request=
, but that expectation is just that: an expectation. And it might fail anyt=
ime.

Yes, this should comprise part of a shared understanding.

> Talking =
about 'shared understanding' or 'varying semantics of POST requests' implie=
s that there are application level semantics on top of HTTP. There are not,=
 HTTP is all the contract there is.
>

If by 'application level' you mean '=
Layer 7 in the OSI model', then
what are we required to use for this? There=
 are already uses of
"application" beyond OSI; such as the one in 'hypermed=
ia as the engine
of application state'.

>> The key is that those
>> varyin=
g semantics are _not visible_ on the network and are derived
>> only from t=
he shared understanding between client and server. That's
>> not a violatio=
n of REST constraints or the HTTP spec, it's a small
>> clarification.
>
> =
HTTP is not 'the network' (transport) it is an application protocol (transf=
er) and there are no application semantics layered on top. (Except when you=
 treat HTTP as transfer, of course. As WS-* does)
>
> What you are getting =
wrong, I think, is who knows about the particular applications being execut=
ed. You seem to think that server and client have a shared understanding ab=
out the application (e.g. buying a book at Amazon). They do not. Knowledge =
about the application in a RESTful system is only located on the client. Th=
e server has no idea what application a client is progressing through when =
it sends that POST. The POST means just this 'process this' and the given t=
arget resource will act on the POST as it sees fit.
>

Is there another way=
 to express this, I can't make head nor tail of
it. I think the confusion m=
ight relate to your distinction between
processing 'by the server' vs by 't=
he resource'?

> The client then processes the response with expectations o=
riginating from the application the client is in. The server knows nor shar=
es absolutely nothing about these expectations and has no obligation other =
than to 'process this'.

How can the clients expectation about what and how=
 a given resource
will process a request (success or failure), and how that=
 resource
actually processes the requests not involve shared understanding?=


> The hypermedia you learned from that /123 is an 'image processor' need =
not even come from the same server, you might have received it any number o=
f ways. The server of that /123 resource will not expect that you learned a=
nything about this resource. It will just invoke the mapping function (the =
resource) based on the current request.
>

Unless it was an entry point, a =
client needs some for of shared
understanding in order to know what it was =
meant to POST there?

Cheers,
Mike
